</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Audit Fees include (i)&nbsp;the
integrated audit of the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements, including
statutory audits of the financial statements of the Company&#146;s affiliates, and
of its internal control over financial reporting, and (ii)&nbsp;the reviews of
the Company&#146;s unaudited condensed consolidated interim financial statements
(quarterly financial statements).</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Audit-Related
Fees include professional services in connection with due diligence related to
divestitures and an acquisition, employee benefit plan audits, and procedures
relating to various other audit and special reports.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Tax
Fees include professional services in connection with tax compliance and advice
and preparation of employee expatriate tax returns. Effective in late 2004, the
Company appointed a new service provider for the preparation of expatriate tax
returns. Other than transitional work, the Company no longer uses PricewaterhouseCoopers
for the preparation of expatriate tax returns.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>All fees above include out-of-pocket expenses.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">18</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='18',FILE='C:\fc\7211336987_D11265_1855575\7513-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 11:04 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">RATIFICATION OF THE
SELECTION OF INDEPENDENT AUDITORS<a name="RatificationOfTheSelectionOfIndep_193758"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Audit Committee has selected
PricewaterhouseCoopers as the Company&#146;s independent auditors for the fiscal
year ending December&nbsp;31, 2007 and has further directed that management
submit the selection of independent auditors for ratification by the
stockholders at the Annual Meeting. PricewaterhouseCoopers was the independent
registered public accountants (independent auditor) for the Company for the
2006, 2005, 2004, 2003, 2002 and 2001 fiscal years.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stockholder ratification of the selection of
PricewaterhouseCoopers as the Company&#146;s independent auditors is not required by
the Company&#146;s Amended and Restated By-Laws or otherwise. The Company is
submitting the selection of PricewaterhouseCoopers to stockholders for
ratification as a matter of good corporate practice. If the stockholders fail
to ratify the selection, the Audit Committee will reconsider whether to retain
PricewaterhouseCoopers. Even if the selection is ratified, the Audit Committee,
in its discretion, may direct the appointment of a different independent audit
firm at any time during the year if it determines that such a change would be in
the best interests of the Company and its stockholders.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Representatives of PricewaterhouseCoopers are expected
to be present at the Annual Meeting, will be given an opportunity to make a
statement if they so desire and will be available to respond to appropriate
questions.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Board recommends a vote FOR the ratification of
the selection of PricewaterhouseCoopers.</font></b></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">19</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='19',FILE='C:\fc\7211336987_D11265_1855575\7513-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 11:04 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">COMPENSATION COMMITTEE
MATTERS<a name="CompensationCommitteeMatters_193758"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Scope of Authority<a name="ScopeOfAuthority_193758"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Compensation
Committee&#146;s responsibilities, which are discussed in detail in its charter (Exhibit&nbsp;C),
include, among other duties, the responsibility to:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">e</font>stablish the Company&#146;s executive compensation philosophy;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>assess the appropriateness
and competitiveness of the Company&#146;s executive compensation programs, including
among other elements, severance programs and executive retirement income
design;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>review
and approve goals and objectives of the Chief Executive Officer, evaluate the
performance of the Chief Executive Officer in light of these goals and
objectives and, based upon its evaluation, determine both the elements and
amounts of the Chief Executive Officer&#146;s compensation, as well as perquisites;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>review Management&#146;s
recommendations for, and approve the compensation of, the <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">Chief Executive Officer</font>&#146;s executive direct
reports;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">determine annual incentive compensation, equity awards a</font>nd other
long-term incentive awards granted under the Company&#146;s equity and long-term
incentive plans to eligible participants<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>oversee
the management development and succession planning process (including succession
planning for emergencies) for the Chief Executive Officer and the Chief
Executive Officer&#146;s executive direct reports and, as appropriate, evaluate
potential candidates;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>periodically assess the
appropriateness of and advise the Board regarding the compensation of
independent Directors for service on the Board and its Committees<font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">; and</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;letter-spacing:-.1pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>review<b>  </b>and
discuss with management the Company&#146;s Compensation Discussion and Analysis;
produce and approve <font style="letter-spacing:-.1pt;">the Committee&#146;s annual
report for inclusion in the Company&#146;s annual proxy statement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Any of the Compensation Committee&#146;s responsibilities
designated in the Compensation Committee&#146;s charter may be delegated by the
Compensation Committee to its Chair or another member of the Compensation
Committee, unless prohibited by law, regulation or any NYSE listing standard.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Processes and Procedures.<a name="ProcessesAndProcedures__052157"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Compensation
Committee&#146;s primary processes for establishing and overseeing executive
compensation can also be found in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis. Additional
processes and procedures include:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Meetings</i>. The Compensation Committee meets several times
each year (11 times in 2006). The Chair of the Compensation Committee, with
input from management and the other members of the Compensation Committee,
develops the agenda and determines the frequency and length of Committee
meetings.</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Role of Independent Consultant</i>. The Compensation Committee
has retained Hewitt Associates as its independent compensation consultant to
assist the Compensation Committee in evaluating executive compensation programs
and in recommending the amount and form of executive and director compensation.
The use of an independent consultant provides additional assurance that the
Company&#146;s executive compensation programs are reasonable and consistent with
Company objectives. The independent consultant is engaged directly by the
Compensation Committee. The independent consultant regularly participates in
committee meetings and advises the Compensation Committee with respect to
compensation trends and best practices, plan design, and the reasonableness of
individual compensation awards. In addition, with respect to the chief
executive officer, the consultant prepares the specific compensation
recommendations for the Compensation Committee&#146;s consideration; the CEO does
not participate in the development of the recommendations and has no knowledge
of the recommendations when they are presented to the Compensation Committee. The
independent consultant will play a similar role in recommending the amount or
form of director compensation.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">20</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='20',FILE='C:\fc\7211336987_D11265_1855575\7513-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 11:04 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Role of
Executive Officers and Management</i>. Each year, the Chief Executive
Officer presents to the Compensation Committee her compensation recommendations
for each of the named executive officers (excluding the Chief Executive
Officer), her remaining direct reports and other executive officers. The
Compensation Committee reviews and discusses these recommendations with the
Chief Executive Officer and has full discretion over all recommended
compensation actions. Executive officers do not play a role in determining or
recommending the amount or form of director compensation.</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Compensation Committee
Interlocks and Insider Participation<a name="CompensationCommitteeInterlocksAn_193800"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">None of the
Compensation Committee members:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>has
ever been an officer or employee of the Company;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>is
or was a participant in a &#147;related person&#148; transaction in 2006 (see page&nbsp;63
for a description of our policy on related person transactions); or</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>is an executive officer of
another entity, at which one of our executive officers serves on the board of
directors of such entity.</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Compensation Committee
Report for the Year Ended December&nbsp;31, 2006<a name="CompensationCommitteeReportForThe_193800"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Compensation Committee oversees the Company&#146;s
compensation program on behalf of the Board. In fulfilling its oversight
responsibilities, the Compensation Committee reviewed and discussed with
management the Compensation Discussion and Analysis set forth in this Proxy
Statement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In reliance on the review and discussion referred to
above, the Compensation Committee recommended to the Board that the Compensation
Discussion and Analysis be included in the Company&#146;s Proxy Statement to be
filed in connection with the Company&#146;s 2007 Annual Meeting of Stockholders and
incorporated by reference to the Company&#146;s Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K
for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, each of which will be filed
with the Securities and Exchange Commission.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Compensation Committee:</font></b></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">Deborah C.
Wright, Chair<a name="DeborahC_WrightChair_193800"></a><br>
Ajay Banga<a name="AjayBanga_193801"></a><br>
Jan Bennink<a name="JanBennink_193801"></a><br>
John C. Pope<a name="JohnC_Pope_193801"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The information
contained in the report above shall not be deemed to be &#147;soliciting material&#148;
or to be &#147;filed&#148; with the Securities and Exchange Commission, nor shall such
information be incorporated by reference into any future filing under the
Securities Act of 1933, as amended, or the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as
amended, except to the extent that the Company specifically incorporates it by
reference in such filing.</font></i></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">21</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='21',FILE='C:\fc\7211336987_D11265_1855575\7513-1-dg.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 11:04 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Compensation
Discussion and Analysis<a name="CompensationDiscussionAndAnalysis_210248"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
purpose of the Compensation Discussion and Analysis is to provide our
stockholders with:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>material
information about the objectives of the Company&#146;s executive compensation
program and policies;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>context
and perspective to the tabular and narrative disclosures which follow; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>a
description of the Company&#146;s compensation program design and an explanation of
how executive compensation decisions reflect both the Company&#146;s performance and
stated compensation objectives for the Company&#146;s named executive officers.</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Objectives of the Company&#146;s Compensation Program<a name="ObjectivesOfTheCompanysCompensati_210249"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The four
primary goals of the Company&#146;s compensation program are to:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">1.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>attract,
retain, and motivate talented employees and develop world-class leaders;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>support
business strategies that promote growth, societal alignment and integrity of
conduct within the Company and appropriately balance short and long-term
objectives;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">3.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>align
pay and performance by placing a significant portion of an executive officer&#146;s
compensation at risk and subject to the achievement of financial goals and
other critical strategic and individual objectives; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">4.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>align
the interests of executives and stockholders through stock ownership
guidelines, equity-based incentive awards and long-term cash incentive awards
that link executive compensation to sustained and superior stockholder return.</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Design of the Compensation Program<a name="DesignOfTheCompensationProgram_210249"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Company uses each element of compensation to satisfy one or more of its stated
compensation objectives. &#160;To ensure
appropriate linkage to these objectives, the Company periodically reviews the
goals and levels of each element of compensation. The executive compensation program is designed to achieve the Company&#146;s
objectives by:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Benchmarking. </i>Through an annual review of target and actual
data of our peers, the Company benchmarks its compensation levels and pay mix
with a peer group of companies referred to as the &#147;Compensation Survey Group.&#148;&#160; The Company uses this comparison to ensure
that compensation and benefits levels as a whole are competitive with the
Compensation Survey Group (please see page&nbsp;23 for a further discussion on
the Compensation Survey Group). In addition, the Company compares its financial
performance against a separate performance peer group. The Company uses this
comparison to ensure that its incentive programs are in support of delivering
both superior financial results relative to industry peers and superior
stockholder returns to investors (see the Performance Graph in the consolidated
financial statements contained in the Company&#146;s Form 10-K for the year ended
December 31, 2006).</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Providing Fixed and Variable Compensation. </i>The Company
provides a mix of fixed and variable compensation designed to attract, retain,
and motivate top-performing executives as well as appropriately link
compensation levels with the achievement of relevant financial and strategic
goals (please see page&nbsp;24 for specific pay mix information);</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Providing Equity and Cash Incentives. </i>The Company provides a
mix between equity and cash incentives to focus executives on delivering on
performance measures that drive long-term sustainable stockholder returns
(please see page&nbsp;24 for specific pay mix information);</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Assessing Individual Performance. </i>Actual awards are
differentiated between participants based upon individual performance and their
potential for advancement within the Company, while ensuring fairness and
discipline in our performance ratings (please see page&nbsp;25 for a further
discussion); and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font><i>Requiring Stock Ownership. </i>Stock ownership by executives is
required to further align interests of executives with the interests of our
stockholders (please see page&nbsp;25 for a further discussion).</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">22</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='22',FILE='C:\fc\72151426571_D10466_1856976\7513-1-di.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 15:15 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">2006
Compensation Survey Group</font></u></i></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Composition of the 2006 Compensation Survey Group</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company performs an annual
comparison of its compensation levels with that of similar positions at
companies comprising the Compensation Survey Group. This annual review is
designed to ensure that the Company&#146;s compensation programs and target
compensation levels are in line with market practice. This ensures the Company&#146;s
ability to attract and retain the level of talent it needs to drive sustainable
top-tier stockholder returns. In determining appropriate compensation levels
for the named executive officers, including Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld, the Committee
reviews compensation levels delivered by companies comprising the Compensation
Survey Group for comparable positions.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To ensure
that the most appropriate companies are selected for the Compensation Survey
Group, the Committee considers companies which meet the following criteria:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>are
of similar revenue size;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>have
a global focus;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>are
recognized for their industry leadership and brand recognition;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>have
executive positions similar in breadth, complexity and scope of responsibility;
and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>compete
with the Company for executive talent.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Based on the above criteria,
the companies comprising the 2006 Compensation Survey Group were as follows:
Anheuser-Busch Companies,&nbsp;Inc., Campbell Soup Company, The Clorox Company,
The Coca-Cola Company, Colgate-Palmolive Company, ConAgra Foods,&nbsp;Inc.,
General Mills,&nbsp;Inc., H.J. Heinz Company, Hershey Foods Corporation,
Johnson&nbsp;&amp; Johnson, Kellogg Company, Kimberly-Clark Corporation,
PepsiCo,&nbsp;Inc., The Procter&nbsp;&amp; Gamble Company, and Sara Lee
Corporation.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competitive positioning in 2006</font></i></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s compensation
practices and pay levels relative to those companies within the 2006
Compensation Survey Group are described below. The median revenue size of the
2006 Compensation Survey Group at $11.6 billion is approximately one-third the
size of the Company. Due to the Company&#146;s revenue size relative to the median of
the 2006 Compensation Survey Group, the Committee determined that based on the
companies included in the 2006 Compensation Survey Group, it was appropriate to
design programs and set target level compensation that delivered total
compensation for executives between the 50</font><font size="1" style="font-size:6.5pt;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">th</font>&#160;and the 75<font size="1" style="font-size:6.5pt;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">th</font>&#160;percentiles of
the 2006 Compensation Survey Group, upon attainment of targeted financial and
strategic goals. Actual total compensation can exceed the 75<font size="1" style="font-size:6.5pt;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">th</font>&#160;percentile when business objectives and
individual performance significantly exceed targeted goals, and upon
achievement of superior performance relative to the 2006 Compensation Survey
Group. This positioning ensures that executives are paid competitively when
considering the relative size and complexity of the companies that comprise the
2006 Compensation Survey Group.</p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Competitive
Review Completed in November&nbsp;2006</font></u></i></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Composition of the 2007 Compensation Survey Group</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During 2006, in consultation
with Hewitt Associates in their role as the Committee&#146;s independent consultant,
the Committee reviewed the companies included in the 2006 Compensation Survey
Group. After careful review, the Committee determined that the following
companies meet the stated criteria and will comprise the 2007 Compensation
Survey Group for purposes of 2007 compensation comparisons and analysis: Abbott
Laboratories, Anheuser-Busch Companies,&nbsp;Inc., Bristol-Myers Squibb, The
Coca-Cola Company, Colgate-Palmolive Company, ConAgra Foods,&nbsp;Inc., Eli
Lilly and Company, General Mills,&nbsp;Inc., Johnson&nbsp;&amp; Johnson,
Kellogg Company, Kimberly-Clark Corporation, McDonald&#146;s Corporation, Merck&nbsp;&amp;
Co.,&nbsp;Inc., Nestle, PepsiCo,&nbsp;Inc., Pfizer Inc., The Procter&nbsp;&amp;
Gamble Company, Sara Lee Corporation, Unilever, The Walt Disney Company, and
Wyeth. The companies comprising the 2007 Compensation Survey Group provide a
better </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">23</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='23',FILE='C:\fc\72151426571_D10466_1856976\7513-1-di.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 15:15 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">representative group of
companies based on size, complexity and their reflection as a globally diverse
set of consumer products companies known for their industry leadership. The
median revenue size of the new Compensation Survey Group is $20.5 billion
compared to the former group at $11.6 billion, based on the most recent
available data. Based on revenue size, the 2007 Compensation Survey Group
provides a better comparison based on the Company&#146;s revenue of $34.4 billion in
2006.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Competitive positioning in 2007</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee approved a
change in the Company&#146;s compensation philosophy to target compensation at the
median of the 2007 Compensation Survey Group. The Company&#146;s compensation
programs are positioned to deliver pay above the median of the 2007
Compensation Survey Group when both superior business and individual
performance is achieved.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Pay Mix in
2006</font></u></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company uses each of its elements
of compensation to satisfy one or more of its stated compensation objectives. &#160;To ensure appropriate linkage to these
objectives, the Company periodically reviews its pay mix of these elements. In
determining the appropriate mix, the Company considered the practices and
levels of its peers in the 2006 Compensation Survey Group to help ensure the
Company&#146;s continued ability to attract and retain its executives. The Company
places a significant portion of compensation &#147;at-risk.&#148;&#160; The rationale for this is to ensure that an
executive&#146;s compensation is linked to financial and individual performance
goals that drive sustainable growth in total stockholder return. Also, the
Company bases a significant amount of its variable compensation on the
achievement of long-term results (as represented by the restricted stock and
cash-based long-term incentive compensation elements). This is to focus
executives on managing the business in a manner that will generate long-term
sustainable growth in total stockholder return.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company has no specific
pre-established policies or targets for the allocation between either cash and
non-cash or short-term and long-term compensation. However, by design, and as
shown in the chart below, a significant portion of compensation is variable or &#147;performance-based&#148;
with a majority skewed to long-term compensation. This is to ensure that
compensation delivered to the named executive officers is aligned with the
interests of stockholders and drives sustained superior stockholder return. The
Committee also reviews competitive information provided by Hewitt Associates to
compare the Company&#146;s pay mix to the Compensation Survey Group to ensure that
significant differences do not exist that would negatively impact the Company&#146;s
ability to attract and retain world-class executives.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">24</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='24',FILE='C:\fc\72151426571_D10466_1856976\7513-1-di.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 15:15 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The chart
below provides a comparison of the Company&#146;s total compensation and benefits
mix, on average, for the named executive officers, based on target awards in
2006 against the median of the 2006 Compensation Survey Group.</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="395" colspan="3" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:296.55pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Equity Awards</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="12" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.25pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">%</font></i></p>
  </td>

  </td>
  <td width="29" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:21.8pt;">

  </td>

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="395" colspan="3" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:296.55pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cash Long-Term Incentive</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">

  </td>

  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:18.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">16</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0.375pt 0pt;width:9.25pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">%</font></i></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="29" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:21.75pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:18.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="29" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0.375pt 0pt;width:21.8pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">%</font></i></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.25pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="395" colspan="3" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:296.55pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:bold;">Total</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.5pt;">

  </td>

  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">%</font></i></p>
  </td>

  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="24" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:double windowtext 2.25pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:18.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">100</font></p>

  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">%</font></i></p>
  </td>

  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

</table>

</div>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="80" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:59.75pt;"></div>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Reflects the median of
the Compensation Survey Group based on information provided by Hewitt
Associates.</p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Assessing
Individual Performance</font></u></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Each year,
the Chief Executive Officer presents to the Committee her compensation
recommendations for each of the named executive officers (excluding the Chief
Executive Officer), her remaining direct reports and other officers. The
Committee reviews and discusses these recommendations with the Chief Executive
Officer, taking into account the various factors noted below, and has full
discretion over all recommended compensation actions. Specifically, in assessing individual performance in the context
of making executive compensation decisions, the Committee considers the
following:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>an
executive&#146;s contributions to the Company&#146;s overall performance;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>a
qualitative review of individual performance relative to pre-established goals
discussed at the beginning of the performance cycle;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>an
executive&#146;s leadership capabilities; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>the executive&#146;s potential
for future advancement or ability to assume roles of greater responsibility.</p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">Stock
Ownership Guidelines<a name="StockOwnershipGuidelines_210252"></a></font></u></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stock
ownership guidelines were introduced in 2003 to further align the interests of
approximately 180 executives, including the named executive officers, with
those of the Company&#146;s stockholders. Under the guidelines, executives are
expected to hold common stock in an amount equal to a multiple of their base
salary as determined by their position in the Company by a specified deadline. An
executive&#146;s multiple can be satisfied by meeting the lesser of the specified
number of shares or dollar value. Guidelines are determined using either (i)&nbsp;the
base salary rate at the time an individual becomes an executive, or (ii)&nbsp;the
base salary rate as of the date an executive is promoted to a higher level in
the organization. The guidelines range from two to twelve times base salary. For
the named executive officers, the guidelines, as a multiple of base salary, are
as follows:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="80" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:60.0pt;">
  <p style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><!-- SET mrlNoTableShading -->Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld</p>
  </td>
  <td width="73" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:55.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="60" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:45.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Mr.&nbsp;Dollive</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="53" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:40.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="66" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:49.15pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Mr.&nbsp;Roberts</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:35.85pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="56" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.2pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Mr.&nbsp;Searer</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:36.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="80" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:60.2pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="80" valign="top" style="border:none;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:60.0pt;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">12 times</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="73" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:55.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="60" valign="top" style="border:none;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:45.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="53" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:40.0pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="66" valign="top" style="border:none;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:49.15pt;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5 times</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:35.85pt;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="56" valign="top" style="border:none;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:42.2pt;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5 times</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="48" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:36.0pt;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="80" valign="top" style="border:none;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:60.2pt;">
  <p align="center" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">5 times</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">25</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='25',FILE='C:\fc\72151426571_D10466_1856976\7513-1-di.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 15:15 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Executives are expected to
attain their ownership levels within five years of becoming an executive or
within three years of being promoted to a higher level within the executive
ranks. The Company monitors stock ownership levels to ensure that executives
are on track to meet or exceed their stock ownership levels within the
specified timeframe. Stock ownership is defined as direct ownership of Company
common stock, including sole ownership, dividend reinvestment plan shares,
restricted shares, and accounts over which the executive has direct or indirect
ownership or control. This definition does not include unexercised Company
stock options. If an executive does not meet the guideline level in the
required timeline, the Chairman has the flexibility to take any further action
as deemed appropriate depending on the particular circumstances of the
executive&#146;s situation. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, all named executive
officers maintain a stock ownership level at or above their respective
ownership guidelines, with the exception of Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld. Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld
will have five years from her appointment as Chief Executive Officer to attain
her stock ownership levels.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Elements of Executive Compensation<a name="ElementsOfExecutiveCompensation_210253"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The
Company&#146;s executive compensation program consists of:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>base
salary,</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>annual
cash incentives,</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>long-term
cash and equity incentives,</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>retirement,
health and welfare benefits, and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>perquisites.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A description of each of the
compensation program elements follows.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Base Salary</font></u></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Base salary is the &#147;fixed&#148;
element of executive compensation aimed at attracting, retaining, and
motivating talented employees and used to compensate named executive officers
for services rendered during the fiscal year. The Committee considers a number
of factors when reviewing and setting base salaries: Company performance, the
executive&#146;s individual performance and performance rating, level of
responsibility, tenure, prior experience, and a comparison of base salaries
paid for comparable positions at companies in the 2006 Compensation Survey
Group. The Committee does not assign a particular weight to any factor.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Salaries are reviewed on an
annual basis and merit increases are considered for all executives and are
generally effective April&nbsp;1.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At the beginning of 2006, the
Committee decided not to award merit increases for the named executive officers
and other senior executives. This decision reflected the Company&#146;s 2005
financial performance which trailed expectations and a decline in stockholder
return.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee retains the
discretion to provide base salary increases to certain named executive officers
in the event that a named executive officer was appointed to a position of
increased responsibility. As such, in 2006, Mr.&nbsp;Searer received a base
salary increase in recognition of his promotion to his current position.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Annual Cash
Incentives</font></u></i></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Overview</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The annual cash incentive
award program is designed to motivate and reward participants, including the
named executive officers, for achieving the Company&#146;s annual financial and
strategic goals. At the beginning of each year, each participant in the plan is
assigned a pre-communicated target award as a percentage of base salary
reflecting his or her role and responsibilities within the Company (please see
the individual target award percentages for the named executive officers on
page 27). The target award percentage may be adjusted during the year if the
role or responsibilities are changed. As further described below, this
individual target award is adjusted at the end of the year to reflect the
Company&#146;s and the individual&#146;s actual performance.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">26</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='26',FILE='C:\fc\72151426571_D10466_1856976\7513-1-di.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 15:15 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At the beginning of each year, the Committee and
management set financial and strategic objectives for the Company. At the
conclusion of each year, the Committee assesses the Company&#146;s performance. This
assessment is a quantitative and qualitative review of the financial and
strategic achievements versus the goals set by the Company at the beginning of
the year. This assessment takes into account financial results relative to the
business plan in addition to the manner in which results were achieved. The
Committee also assesses the Company&#146;s total stockholder return (TSR) relative
to a performance peer group and other major indices, such as the Standard&nbsp;&amp;
Poors 500 index. The performance peer group consists of companies considered
market competitors of the Company, or that have been selected on the basis of
industry, level of management complexity, global focus or industry leadership. While
there is substantial overlap between the performance peer group companies and
the companies in the Compensation Survey Group, the major difference between
the two groups is that the performance peer group companies are more heavily
focused on the food and beverage industry and are included regardless of
revenue size. A list of the performance peer group companies is disclosed in
the footnote to the Performance Graph in the consolidated financial statements
contained in the Company&#146;s Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Based on this assessment, business unit ratings are
assigned to the Kraft North America Commercial and Kraft International
Commercial business segments and the Company as a whole and are used to
determine the size of the annual incentive pool. These business unit ratings
also serve to adjust up or down the individual target award percentage for each
participant. For context, if the Company financial and strategic goals are
satisfied in a given year for the Company as a whole, the Committee is likely
to assign a 100% rating to the Company. If results exceed objectives, the
rating assigned to the Company will likely be higher than 100%, and likewise,
if results are below expectations, the rating assigned to the Company will
likely be below 100%.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Once this pool is created, individual awards are then
allocated based on individual contributions by each of the participants. Actual
awards are then based on individual performance and can range from 0% to
approximately 200% of the adjusted target award.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For the named executive
officers whose compensation is subject to the tax deductibility limitations of Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of
the Internal Revenue Code (&#147;covered employees&#148;), maximum annual incentive award
levels are based upon the level of achievement of adjusted net earnings derived
from a compensation formula set by the Committee (please see details of this
calculation under the Policy With Respect To Qualifying Compensation for Tax
Deductibility section on page&nbsp;34). Actual annual incentive awards earned
by named executive officers in 2006 were tax deductible and are presented in
the Summary Compensation Table on page&nbsp;37.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2006 Annual Cash
Incentive Plan Design</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2006, the Committee
considered a number of </font>financial measures including the following: net revenue, volume, operating companies
income, operating companies income margin, discretionary cash flow, total
stockholder return, and earnings per share. Each financial measure, with the
exception of total stockholder return, in 2006 was measured against actual
prior year results and the Company&#146;s 2006 business plan.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee also evaluated the Company&#146;s performance
against other strategic measures such as market share, portfolio management,
societal alignment, diversity and leadership development. &#160;No specific weight was assigned to the factors
considered.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee believes that focusing on these measures
will lead to sustainable growth in total stockholder return.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Target
awards levels, as a percentage of base salary, for the named executive officers
as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 were as follows:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">27</font></p>

<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee retains complete
discretion in evaluating the Company&#146;s results relative to the financial and
strategic goals.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Actual 2006 Performance
Relative to Objectives.</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&nbsp; </i>Based
on its quantitative and qualitative review of the results in 2006, the Committee
assigned the following ratings to the Company and its business units as
follows:</p>

<div align="center">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">

  </td>

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="495" colspan="3" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:371.2pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Kraft International

  </td>

  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="43" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:32.25pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">105%</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt 0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:9.25pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;font-weight:bold;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">These ratings reflect the
Committee&#146;s assessment of the Company&#146;s progress relative to the financial and
strategic goals set at the beginning of the year. These ratings will have an
impact of adjusting an individual&#146;s target awards by the applicable rating,
depending on which business unit the individual is aligned to during the
performance period. An overview of these results follows.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company delivered mixed
financial results in 2006. Many business fundamentals were improved and several
key businesses responded well. However, the turnaround was not broad-based
enough and the foundation for sustained top-tier performance is not yet in
place.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company continued to focus
on building top-line momentum, with organic revenue improving versus historical
performance. Improved top line performance also translated into an overall
increase in U.S. market share. Brand value investments also significantly
improved pricing ability in certain segments.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">However, there were areas of
the business where results fell short of expectations. The Company experienced
share declines in several key categories. Manufacturing cost challenges drove
higher than expected cost increases despite solid productivity gains. <i>Tassimo</i> fell significantly short of plan expectations,
resulting in a significant pre-tax asset write-down of $245 million.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s TSR improved in
2006. TSR measures the Company&#146;s annual share price growth including reinvested
dividends and provides the Company with the clearest link to the creation and
growth of stockholder value. The Company&#146;s TSR of 30.5% outperformed the
performance peer group median TSR of 23.0% and the S&amp;P 500 index of 15.8%.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The results, including the TSR
performance, all contributed to the overall assessment and subsequent ratings
of the business units. As stated earlier, no specific weight was assigned to
any of the financial or strategic measures.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Upon her appointment as Chief
Executive Officer, Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld was guaranteed a minimum annual incentive
award of $1,950,000. This guarantee recognized the amount she would have
otherwise been paid had she remained with her previous employer. The actual
award of $2,500,000 she received recognized her contributions to the
performance of the Company in 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The other named executive
officers&#146; actual awards were based on an assessment of business and individual
performance in the manner described above.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Actual award amounts are
presented in the Summary Compensation Table on page&nbsp;37.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><u><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:normal;">Long-Term
Incentives</font></u></i></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Overview</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">To focus its executives on
operational performance that leads to increased long-term stockholder returns,
and to address stockholder dilution concerns, long-term incentive awards are
delivered to executives through a combination of cash-based long-term performance
incentive awards (approximately 40% of the total long-term value) and
restricted stock (approximately 60% of the total long-term value). In the past,
the Committee has </font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">28</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='28',FILE='C:\fc\71204532394_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:46 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">granted stock options to
executives; however, as further discussed below, the Committee has not granted
new stock options to any executive since 2001.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cash-Based Long-Term Incentive Plan Awards</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Long-Term Incentive Plan awards
reward executives for the achievement of long-term financial and strategic
goals during the applicable performance cycle and are primarily designed to
reward participants for the achievement of top-tier stockholder return.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The primary measure considered
by the Committee for this incentive program is TSR performance relative to the
performance peer group and major indices, such as the S&amp;P 500 during the
period. At the beginning of the
performance cycle, and in addition to the TSR measure, the Committee considers
secondary financial measures including revenue, volume, operating
companies income, net earnings, diluted earnings per share, and discretionary
cash flow. In addition, the Committee considers secondary strategic measures
such as portfolio management, societal alignment, diversity and leadership
development. These measures are established and approved by the Committee at
the beginning of the three-year long-term performance cycle. No specific weight
is assigned to any of these secondary financial or strategic measures.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Each participant in the plan
is assigned a pre-communicated target award as a percentage of cumulative
year-end base salaries over the three-year performance cycle reflecting his or
her role and responsibilities within the Company. Participants who become
eligible to participate in this incentive plan during the performance cycle are
eligible to receive a pro-rated award from the initial date of participation
through the end of the performance cycle.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">At the conclusion of each
performance cycle, the Committee completes a quantitative and qualitative
assessment of the Company&#146;s performance during the performance cycle. Based on
this review, the Committee assigns a rating to the Company which is used to determine the size of the
long-term incentive pool. This
performance rating provides a method to adjust individual target percentages up
or down for each participant. For context, if TSR is at the median of the
performance peer group and the Company&#146;s financial and strategic goals are
satisfied in a given performance cycle, the Committee is likely to assign a
100% rating to the Company. If TSR is above the median of the performance peer
group or other major indices and other financial and strategic achievements
exceed objectives, the Company&#146;s assigned rating will likely be above 100%, and
likewise, if results are below expectations, the rating assigned will likely be
below 100%.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Once this pool is created,
individual awards may be allocated based on individual contributions by each of
the participants. Actual awards are then based on individual performance and
typically range from approximately 90% to 110% of the adjusted target award.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee retains full
discretion and assesses actual results against prescribed performance measures
to decide award levels.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">2004&#151;2006 Long-Term Incentive Plan Design</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Participants in the 2004&#151;2006
performance cycle included approximately 180 executives. This long-term
performance cycle was a three-year, end-to-end cycle, which began on January&nbsp;1,
2004 and concluded on December&nbsp;31, 2006. Awards were paid to participants
in cash.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Target
awards levels, as a percentage of cumulative year-end base salaries, for the
named executive officers as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 were as follows:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="134" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.65pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="134" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.7pt;">

  </td>
  <td width="134" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:100.65pt;">
