  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Actual
2004&#151;2006 Performance Relative to Objectives.</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&nbsp; </i>Based on its quantitative and qualitative assessment
of the 2004&#151;2006 performance cycle, the Committee assigned the Company a rating
of 70%.</p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">29</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='29',FILE='C:\fc\71204532394_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:46 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">During the 2004&#151;2006 performance cycle, the Company&#146;s
TSR was 20.2%. Although positive, the Company&#146;s TSR ranked in the bottom
quartile of the performance peer group. This return also lagged the S&amp;P 500
index return of 34.7% during the period. Financial performance during the
performance cycle, including operating income and earnings per share growth,
also fell short of objectives. The financial shortfalls were due to below plan
volume performance; significantly higher than expected commodity costs;
investments in quality/packaging and new product initiatives; higher pension and
benefit costs; and investment in price gap management.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Despite disappointing financial performance during the
three-year period, a number of strategic initiatives were implemented to
position the Company for future growth. Specifically, during the performance
cycle the Company initiated a major restructuring program that is expected to
result in savings of $1 billion per year following completion in 2008;
increased new product revenues; and accelerated growth in developing markets.
In addition, during the performance period, the Company divested a number of
slower growing and/or lower margin businesses. The Company also completed a few
acquisitions, such as a U.S.-based beverage business and the United Biscuit
business in Iberia.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Ms.&#160; Rosenfeld&#146;s award under this three-year cycle was set at a target
based on her full year 2006 salary, in accordance with her offer letter. Her
actual $3,250,000 award recognized amounts she would have otherwise been paid
had she remained with her previous employer.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For the other named executive
officers, actual awards for individuals were equal to 70% of their respective
target award without any adjustment for individual performance.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 11.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Actual award amounts are
presented in the Summary Compensation Table on page&nbsp;37.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Equity Compensation</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee uses equity as
an element of compensation to align the interests of our executives with those
of our stockholders. Since 2003, the Committee has granted equity to the named
executive officers in the form of restricted stock.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Restricted Stock.</font></i></font>&nbsp;&nbsp; The
Committee has determined that restricted stock is an appropriate form of equity
compensation because it:</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>directly
builds executive stock ownership and aligns the interests of management with
those of stockholders;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>enhances
executive retention and commitment;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>efficiently
uses shares resulting in lower share utilization; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>establishes
a transparent cost basis.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For 2006, the Committee
awarded grants of restricted stock (or deferred stock for participants in
countries outside of the U.S.) to eligible employees. Restricted stock awards
are granted annually at the Committee&#146;s regularly scheduled January&nbsp;meeting.
Annual awards are granted on the date of the meeting and are based on the fair
market value of the Company&#146;s stock on such date. The fair market value is
defined as the average of the high and low traded stock prices on the New York
Stock Exchange on the date of grant. The award levels are based on an analysis
of competitive market practice, a qualitative review of an executive&#146;s
performance during the previous year and an evaluation of each executive&#146;s
potential to advance within the organization.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Annual restricted stock awards
vest entirely on the third anniversary of the date of the award. The three-year
cliff vesting provides a strong retention element. Recipients of restricted
stock receive cash dividends on the shares of restricted stock granted to them
at the same time and in the same amounts as the Company&#146;s stockholders. Dividends
paid are considered ordinary income for individual tax purposes.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">30</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='30',FILE='C:\fc\71204532394_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:46 2007' -->

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Target
awards levels, expressed in grant value terms (which is calculated by
multiplying the number of shares at grant to the fair market value of the
Company&#146;s Common Stock on the date of the grant), for the named executive
officers as of January&nbsp;24, 2006 were as follows:</font></p>

<div align="center" style="font-family:Times New Roman;">

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="80" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:59.75pt;"></div>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Ms.
Rosenfeld was not employed by the Company on the date of the 2006 annual grant.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Actual awards can generally
range from 0&#151;150% of target. Actual award amounts in 2006 are presented in the
Grants of Plan-Based Awards table on page&nbsp;40.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company may from time to
time grant off-cycle restricted stock awards to newly-hired executives. The
Committee has delegated limited authority to the Chairman to grant off-cycle
stock grants to newly-hired executives, subject to certain guidelines approved
by the Committee. The Company is then required to report any such grants to the
Committee at its next regularly scheduled meeting.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">This delegation authority is
limited by a maximum number of shares that can be granted to any individual. The
limitations include the aggregate amount of shares permitted to be granted in a
single year; the number of new employees to whom such stock awards may be
granted in a single year; and that only apply to newly-hired employees that are
not subject to Section&nbsp;16 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 or Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of
the Internal Revenue Code. The purpose for this delegation of authority to the
Chairman is to provide management with flexibility in making competitive offers
to potential candidates in a timely manner, within a reasonable set of
guidelines.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2006, the Committee granted Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld a </font>sign-on
restricted stock award of 387,230 shares with a grant value of $12 million,
primarily to offset compensation awards granted by her previous employer that
were subsequently forfeited as a result of her resignation, and to provide an
inducement for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld to join the Company. The terms and conditions
substantially similar to grants made to other executives with the following
exceptions:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">i.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>161,346
shares will vest July&nbsp;1, 2009 and the remaining 225,884 shares will vest
on July&nbsp;1, 2011, provided that if, prior to full vesting of the shares
granted, Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s employment with the Company ends due to
involuntary termination for reasons other than cause, the total number of
unvested shares will continue to vest on the vesting dates stated above;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ii.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The
total number of shares will also vest if (1)&nbsp;she fails to be named
Chairman of the Company&#146;s Board of Directors on or before January&nbsp;1, 2008
or (2)&nbsp;anyone other than Mr.&nbsp;Camilleri or Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld is
appointed Chairman of the Company&#146;s Board of Directors.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Also, in 2006, the Committee
granted Mr.&nbsp;Searer an off-cycle restricted stock award of $2 million in
recognition of his promotion to President, Kraft North America Commercial. This
restricted stock award will vest entirely on the fourth anniversary of the date
of the award.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stock Options.</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&nbsp; </i>Consistent with the Committee&#146;s decision to make
equity awards in shares of restricted stock, the Committee did not make any
stock option grants during 2006. The Committee has not granted new stock
options to named executive officers since the initial public offering in June&nbsp;2001.
Stock options granted to named executive officers prior to the Company&#146;s
initial public offering in June&nbsp;2001 were options to acquire Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc.
Common Stock. All outstanding stock options have 10-year expiration
periods and many executives continue to hold options on both Company Common
Stock and on Altria Group, Inc. Common Stock.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 4.5pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stock options on both Altria Group,
Inc. and Company stock that were granted prior to 2003 to a limited number of
the Company&#146;s most senior executives have an Executive Ownership Stock Option (&#147;EOSO&#148;)
feature. The EOSO feature was implemented to promote the earlier exercise of
stock options and the retention of Company shares to build share ownership
among the Company&#146;s senior executives. None of the named executive officers
received EOSOs in 2006 in connection with an exercise of previously granted
stock options. All outstanding stock options with an EOSO feature will expire
no later than 2011.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">31</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='31',FILE='C:\fc\71204532394_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dk.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:46 2007' -->



<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">
<div>


<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Perquisites </font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s named executive officers receive various
perquisites provided by the Company. These perquisites include a car allowance,
a financial counseling allowance and, for the Chief Executive Officer only,
personal use of the corporate aircraft. For reasons of security and personal
safety, the Company requires Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld to use Company aircraft for
both business and personal travel. Taxes on these perquisites are imputed as
income to the executive and taxed accordingly.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Since these perquisites are similar to those provided
to named executive officers at many companies within the Compensation Survey
Group, the Committee believes that they are therefore necessary for retention
and recruitment purposes.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee reviews the perquisites on a periodic
basis, to ensure that they are appropriate in light of the Company&#146;s total
compensation program and market practice.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Specific executive perquisites
are listed in the table on page&nbsp;38. Other than these perquisites,
executives have the same benefits that are generally provided to other
employees.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Post-Termination
Compensation</font></i></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-weight:normal;">Post-termination
compensation consists of both separation pay and retirement benefits.</font></b></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Severance
Agreements and Change-in-Control Agreements.</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&nbsp; </i>The Company does not have specific severance or
change-in-control agreements with any of its actively-employed named executive
officers. Based on the Company&#146;s
ownership structure as of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Committee believed that
change-in-control arrangements were not required.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company maintains a severance plan in the U.S.
that provides for certain severance payments in the event of job elimination or
a workforce reduction. Similar plans are generally available in other countries
where the Company has employees. The plans are implemented for recruitment and retention purposes, as all or
nearly all of the companies with which we compete for executive talent offer
similar benefits to their executives.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company does from time to time, as a practice and
in its own discretion, make payments to executives in the event of an executive&#146;s
termination without cause for reasons that may or may not otherwise qualify for
severance payments under one of the Company&#146;s severance plans. No benefits are
available or have accrued prior to the executive&#146;s employment separation, and
at no time does the executive have rights to severance payments. These benefits
may be in line with the benefits offered under a severance plan or they may be
in excess of benefits offered under a plan. Separation arrangements made with certain executives upon termination
without cause are an important aspect in protecting the Company, since these
payments are typically made in consideration of a general release of future
claims against the Company, non-compete, non-solicitation, non-disparagement
and confidentiality agreements by the executives.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2006, the Company entered into separation
agreements with Messrs.&nbsp;Deromedi and Johnson. The Company entered into
these agreements with Messrs.&nbsp;Deromedi and Johnson for several reasons,
including limiting their ability to directly compete or solicit employees for a
certain period of time. In addition, the provisions of the agreements also
provide that both employees release all claims against the Company and will
keep all material information confidential. The amounts paid under each of the
agreements reflected both the competitive practice for such separations as well
as the value of the restrictive covenants provided for in the agreements. Specific
details of these agreements are presented on pages&nbsp;53 to 55.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Additional information regarding payments typically
made upon termination, including a definition of key terms and a quantification
of benefits that would be received by the Company&#146;s named executive officers
had termination occurred on December&nbsp;31, 2006, is found under the heading
Potential Payments upon Termination or Change-in-Control on pages&nbsp;53 to 58.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">32</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='32',FILE='C:\fc\71204749981_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dm.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:48 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Retirement
Benefits.</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&nbsp; </i>The
purpose of offering retirement benefits to executives is to provide income
protection in the years following an executive&#146;s career with the Company. Retirement
benefits offered to executives are designed to reward an executive&#146;s tenure
with the Company.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Both tax-qualified and supplemental defined benefit
retirement plans are generally offered to executives, including the named
executive officers, and vary by country. The Committee believes that the
retirement benefits offered to executives are important retention and
recruitment elements, as many of the companies that the Company competes with
for talent offer similar programs. Accrued amounts and additional details of
each of the retirement benefit programs offered to the named executive officers
are presented in the Pension Benefits table and the accompanying narrative to
the table beginning on page&nbsp;47.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In connection with her
letter of employment, Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld received an enhanced pension benefit. The
enhanced pension benefit provides for a service bridge for the period of time
that Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld was not employed by the Company between 2004 and 2006. This
enhanced pension benefit recognized that Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld would not be
eligible for a pension benefit under her previous employer&#146;s plan following her
separation</font> from
her previous employer. This pension enhancement provides a continuation of
pension benefits as if Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld had not left the Company for any
period of time. Additional details of this enhanced pension benefit are
presented in the Pension Benefits table and the accompanying narrative to the
table beginning on page&nbsp;47.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mr. Deromedi also received an enhanced pension benefit.
In recognition of Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi&#146;s promotion to Chief Executive Officer of
the Company in 2004, and in connection with his previous pension benefit earned
at General Foods Corporation, the Company will use his final average earnings
at retirement (or earlier separation) for purposes of calculating his pension
benefit. Additional details are presented in the Pension Benefits table and the
accompanying narrative to the table beginning on page&nbsp;47.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Mr. Vogelsang participates in the Kraft Foods
Switzerland Pension Fund. The Kraft Foods Switzerland Pension Fund is a
contributory plan providing benefits related to the participant&#146;s years of
accredited service and final covered compensation. Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang participates
in the Kraft Foods Switzerland Pension Fund as a Swiss-based employee currently
on an international assignment in the U.S. This is the same plan that is
generally available to all eligible employees in Switzerland. Accrued amounts
and additional details of Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang&#146;s retirement benefit programs are
presented in the Pension Benefits table and the accompanying narrative to the
table beginning on page&nbsp;47.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee believes that both the U.S.
tax-qualified and Supplemental Defined Contribution plans are integral parts of
the overall compensation program. The Supplemental Defined Contribution Plan is
important in that it encourages executives, including named executive officers,
to save for retirement. The Committee believes that the Company&#146;s named
executive officers should be allowed to defer the same percentage of their
compensation, and receive the corresponding Company match, as all other
employees, without regard to the compensation limit established by the Internal
Revenue Code with respect to tax-qualified plan contributions. &#160;Accrued amounts and additional details of each
of the non-qualified deferred compensation programs offered to named executive
officers are presented in the Non-Qualified Deferred Compensation table and the
accompanying narrative to the table beginning on page&nbsp;51.</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font style="font-style:italic;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Trust
Payments.</font></i></font><i>&nbsp;&nbsp; </i>Prior to
2005, the Company made payments to individual trusts on behalf of certain
executives, including some of the named executive officers. The funding in these individual trusts served
to offset the benefits payable under the Supplemental Defined Benefit and
Supplemental Defined Contribution plans. The Committee evaluated the cost of
these trust payments and determined it was in the Company&#146;s best interest to
pay those amounts. The Committee&#146;s reason for deciding to pay amounts to
individual trusts was that it believed that for recruitment, retention and
other reasons, the retirement income promised for all employees, whether or not
payable within the limits applicable to tax-qualified plans, should be provided
in a manner ensuring retirement security.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">33</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='33',FILE='C:\fc\71204749981_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dm.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:48 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In 2005, the Committee
decided, due to changes in the U.S. tax laws that it was no longer in the
Company&#146;s best interest to pay these amounts into individual trusts and
discontinued paying amounts into individual trusts for any employees. Therefore,
supplemental benefits earned by executives after 2004 will accrue as unfunded
liabilities.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Employment Agreements<a name="EmploymentAgreements_204612"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">As a general matter, the
Company does not utilize employment agreements. The Company did provide for
certain benefits, greater than those generally made available to other
employees, to Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld as a condition of her employment. These
additional benefits, including the sign-on Restricted stock grant of 387,230
shares with a grant value of $12 million discussed above were primarily granted
to offset compensation awards granted by her previous employer that were
subsequently forfeited as a result of her resignation and to provide an
inducement for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld to join the Company. Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld was
also offered the cost of temporary living accommodations for a one-year period.
This benefit was provided to allow Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld adequate time to relocate
from Texas to Illinois. Specific details of these additional benefits are
presented on page&nbsp;41.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Policy With Respect To
Qualifying Compensation for Tax Deductibility<a name="PolicyWithRespectToQualifyingComp_204612"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s ability to deduct compensation paid to
covered employees, including several named executive officers, for tax purposes
is generally limited by Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of the Internal Revenue Code
to $1.0 million annually. Covered employees include the principal executive
officer and the four highest paid executive officers in the Company. This
limitation does not apply to performance-based compensation, provided certain
conditions are satisfied with the exception of awards paid to Ms. Rosenfeld, the
annual and long-term performance incentives the Committee awarded to named
executive officers in 2006 were subject to, and made in accordance with,
performance-based compensation arrangements previously implemented by the
Company.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Committee has taken appropriate actions, to the
extent it believes feasible, to preserve the tax deductibility of annual cash
incentive and long-term performance awards. However, notwithstanding this
general policy, the Committee has authorized, and will continue to retain the
discretion to authorize, payments that may not be tax deductible, if it
believes that such payments are in the best interest of stockholders. The
Committee determined that it was appropriate to pay Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld an
annual base salary in excess of $1.0 million. This determination will cause a
portion of her base salary to exceed the $1.0 million tax deductibility limit
in the future. In addition, payments and stock grants made in connection with Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s
employment offer, including her $12 million restricted stock award, her Annual
Cash Incentive and Long-Term Incentive Awards were not tax deductible.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">In addition, named executive
officers&#146; income may exceed the $1.0 million tax deductibility limit because of
other elements of their annual compensation, such as perquisites, vesting in
and dividends on restricted stock, payments related to the funding of
retirement benefits, tax reimbursements, and income resulting from payments
made pursuant to plans that do not discriminate in favor of executive officers.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Annual Incentive
Formula</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">A formula is established under
the annual cash incentive plan which determines the maximum amount that can be
paid to those named executive officers whose compensation is subject to the tax
deductibility limitations of Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of the Internal Revenue
Code. Maximum annual incentive award levels are based upon the achievement of
adjusted net earnings derived from a compensation formula set by the Committee.
Under the formula used to establish the award pool, the maximum amount that can
be paid to the covered employees as a group is 0.40% of adjusted net earnings. The
maximum award for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld is one-third of this pool. The remaining two-thirds
of the pool is divided equally among the remaining covered employees. In
addition, individual award amounts are limited to the stockholder-approved
maximum of $10 million as provided in the 2005 Performance Incentive Plan. Under
the annual incentive compensation plan, the Committee has the discretion to
reduce the amount of an award otherwise payable to a named executive officer. This
discretion is commonly referred to as &#147;negative discretion,&#148; since awards may
only be reduced. The annual incentive </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">34</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='34',FILE='C:\fc\71204749981_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dm.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:48 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">compensation plan has been
structured so that the exercise of negative discretion does not adversely
impact the tax deductibility of reduced awards paid to the named executive
officers.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Cash-Based Long-Term
Incentive Plan</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Similar to the annual
incentive plan, for those named executive officers whose compensation is
subject to the tax deductibility limitations of Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of the
Internal Revenue Code, cash-based long-term incentive plan awards are also
contingent upon the achievement of cumulative adjusted net earnings derived
from a compensation formula set by the Committee at the beginning of the
performance cycle. Under the compensation formula used to establish the award
pool, the maximum amount that can be paid to covered employees as a group is
0.40% of cumulative adjusted net earnings during the performance period. The
maximum award for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld is equal to one-third of this pool. The
remaining two-thirds of the pool is divided equally among the remaining covered
employees. In addition, individual award amounts are limited to the
stockholder-approved maximum of $8 million per each year of the performance
period as provided in the 2005 Performance Incentive Plan. Under the cash-based
long-term incentive plan, the Committee has the discretion to apply negative
discretion. The cash-based long-term incentive plan has been structured so that
the exercise of negative discretion does not adversely impact the tax
deductibility of reduced awards paid to the covered employees.</font></p>

<p style="font-style:italic;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Stock Awards</font></i></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><font style="font-size:10.0pt;">Coincident
with the Company&#146;s adoption of</font> Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;123R
in March&nbsp;2006, the Committee approved the use of a stock performance pool
from which restricted stock may be granted, in amounts up to individually
specified proportions of the pool, to those named executive officers whose
compensation is subject to the tax deductibility limitation of
Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code. The January&nbsp;2007
restricted stock awards were made from this performance pool, thus allowing the
Company to secure the maximum allowable tax deduction with respect to
restricted stock awards to be made in 2007. In addition, individual award
amounts are limited to the stockholder-approved maximum of 1.0 million shares,
as provided in the 2005 Performance Incentive Plan. Similar to the Annual
Incentive and Long-Term Incentive Plans, under the restricted stock plan, the
Committee has the discretion to apply negative discretion. The restricted stock
plan has been structured so that the exercise of negative discretion does not
adversely impact the tax deductibility of reduced awards paid to covered
employees. Restricted stock awards granted prior to January&nbsp;2007 will be
limited by Section&nbsp;162(m)&nbsp;of the Internal Revenue Code to $1.0
million annually as the awards vest.</font></p>

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Policy on Recoupment of
Executive Incentive Compensation in the Event of Certain Restatements<a name="PolicyOnRecoupmentOfExecutiveInce_204614"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">If the Board of
Directors or an appropriate Committee of the Board determines that, as a result
of a restatement of the Company&#146;s financial statements, an executive received
more compensation than the executive would have received absent the incorrect
financial statements, then the Board or Committee, in its discretion, may take
such actions as it deems necessary or appropriate to address the events that
gave rise to the restatement and to prevent its recurrence. Such actions may
include, to the extent permitted by applicable law:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Requiring
partial or full repayment of any bonus or other incentive compensation paid to
the executive;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Requiring
repayment of any gains realized on the exercise of stock options or on the
open-market sale of vested shares;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Causing
the partial or full cancellation of restricted stock or deferred stock awards and
outstanding stock options;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Adjusting
the future compensation of such executive; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Dismissing or initiating
legal action against the executive, as the Board or Committee determines to be
in the best interests of the Company.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">35</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='35',FILE='C:\fc\71204749981_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dm.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:48 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Anti-Hedging Policy and
Trading Restrictions<a name="AntihedgingPolicyAndTradingRestri_204614"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">The Company&#146;s current
policy imposes limits on the timing and types of transactions in Kraft
securities permitted by Section&nbsp;16 officers (&#147;officers&#148;). Among other
restrictions, the policy:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Allows
officers to trade Company securities only during window periods (following
earnings releases) and only after they have pre-cleared transactions;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Prohibits
short selling of Company stock or &#147;selling against the box&#148; (failing to deliver
sold securities);</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Prohibits
officers (and any member of the officer&#146;s family sharing the household) from
transactions in puts, calls or other derivative Company securities on an
exchange or in any other organized market, as well as any other derivative or
hedging transactions on Company securities.</p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">36</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='36',FILE='C:\fc\71204749981_D11189_1851664\7513-1-dm.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 12 20:48 2007' -->

<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Summary Compensation Table<a name="SummaryCompensationTable_210157"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><i><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;font-style:italic;">All data
in US Dollars</font></i></p>

<table border="0" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" style="border-collapse:collapse;">
 <tr style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="143" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:107.45pt;">
  <p style="font-size:8.0pt;font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><!-- SET mrlNoTableShading --></p>

  <p style="line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 14.0pt;text-indent:-7.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">Vice President,</font></p>
  <p style="line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 14.0pt;text-indent:-7.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:7.0pt;">Global Supply Chain</font></p>

</div>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="80" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:59.75pt;"></div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)&#160;&#160; The amounts shown in this column include the
value of Restricted Stock awards based on the FAS 123R valuation methodology
that is used to value Restricted Stock awards to all participants. Assumptions
made in the valuation methodology are disclosed in Note 11 to the consolidated
financial statements contained in the Company&#146;s Form&nbsp;10-K for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, with the exception that the valuation shown
in the Summary Compensation Table assumes no forfeitures for active named
executive officers. Grants awarded in 2006 are presented in the &#147;Grants of Plan
Based Awards&#148; table on page&nbsp;40.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(2)&#160;&#160; Amounts shown in this column represent the
remaining amortized compensation cost of stock options granted at the time of
the initial public offering in June 2001. The fair market value at grant date
was $9.13 per stock option using a modified Black-Scholes valuation
methodology. The assumptions used in the valuation methodology are as follows:
risk-free rate of 4.81%; weighted average expected life of five years; expected
volatility of 29.70%; and an expected dividend yield of 1.68%.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(3)&#160;&#160; Amounts shown in the first column include
awards paid under the 2006 Annual Cash Management Incentive Plan and the
amounts in the second column include awards paid under the 2004&#151;2006 Cash Based
Long-Term Incentive Plan. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 5.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(4)&#160;&#160; The amounts shown in this column include the
aggregate increase in actuarial values of each named executive officer&#146;s
benefits under a Company defined benefit program. For U.S. plan participants,
these amounts include the aggregate increase in actuarial values under the U.S.
Tax-Qualified Pension Plan and the U.S. Supplemental Defined Benefit Pension
Plan. For Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang, the amounts include the aggregate increase in
actuarial values of benefits earned under the Switzerland Pension Fund and the
Kraft Foods Germany Pension Plan.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">37</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='37',FILE='C:\fc\72115835736_D10466_1855858\7513-1-do.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 12:00 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(5)&#160;&#160; The amounts shown in this
column for each of the named executive officers include perquisites, the
employer match on defined contribution plan, event related gifts, and tax
reimbursements. Also included are relocation expenses for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld
and severance payments associated with Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi&#146;s and Mr.&nbsp;Johnson&#146;s
separation agreements. </font></p>

  <td width="16" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="5" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="56" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="16" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="5" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="40" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="16" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="5" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="40" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="16" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="5" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="56" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="2" style="border:none;"></td>
 </tr>
</table>

</div>

<p style="line-height:1.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="80" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:59.75pt;"></div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(a)&#160;&#160; For reasons
of security and personal safety, the Company requires Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld to use
the Company aircraft for all travel. For the same reasons, the Company required
that Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi also use the Company aircraft for all travel prior to
his departure. The incremental cost of personal use of Company aircraft
includes the cost of trip-related crew hotels and meals, in-flight food and
beverages, landing and ground handling fees, hourly maintenance contract costs,
hangar or aircraft parking costs, fuel costs based on the average annual cost
of fuel per hour flown, and other smaller variable costs. Fixed costs that
would be incurred in any event to operate Company aircraft (e.g., aircraft
purchase costs, maintenance not related to personal trips, and flight crew
salaries) are not included.&#160;
Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld is responsible for taxes on these amounts and is not
reimbursed for such taxes, with the exception of those amounts associated with
her travels to and from her home during the transition phase detailed in her
offer letter. Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi is responsible for all taxes on these amounts
and is not reimbursed for such taxes. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(b)&#160;&#160; Includes
the value of the named executives officers&#146; use of the Company-provided leased
vehicle for personal reasons and the incremental cost of the Company drivers or
Company-paid limousine service for personal reasons.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(c)&#160;&#160; These trust
assets offset amounts, otherwise payable by the Company, for vested benefits
under non-qualified supplemental retirement plans and are not intended to
increase total promised benefits.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(d)&#160;&#160; Includes amounts
include reimbursable for taxes associated with Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s relocation
to Illinois. The amounts include reimbursements on temporary housing costs, use
of the Company aircraft for the sole purpose of traveling to and from her home,
and costs of ground transportation.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(e)&#160;&#160; Includes
tax equalization payments or reimbursements in connection with a current
international assignment for Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang. These payments or
reimbursements are made pursuant to a policy that is designed to facilitate the
assignment of employees to positions in other countries by covering taxes over
and above those that employees accepting international assignments would have
incurred had they remained in their home countries. Differences in tax periods
used by taxing jurisdictions, time lags </font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">38</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='38',FILE='C:\fc\72115835736_D10466_1855858\7513-1-do.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 12:00 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">in tax determinations or in
the availability of tax credits or refunds, or other factors in some instances
create circumstances in which tax equalization payments are recovered by the
Company in a different year.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 40.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(f)&#160;&#160;&#160; Includes amounts
reimbursable for taxes associated with the event-related gifts given to
Mr.&nbsp;Johnson and Mr.&nbsp;Searer at the 2006 Kraft Nabisco Championship
golf tournament.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(6)&#160;&#160; Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld
was appointed Chief Executive Officer on June&nbsp;26, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(7)&#160;&#160; Per
Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s offer letter, she received a Annual Cash Incentive Plan
award reflective a full year at no less than her annual target amount of
$1,950,000. The actual amount awarded to her was $2,500,000. In addition,
Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s offer letter provides a payment under the 2004&#151;2006
Cash-Based Long-Term Incentive Plan equal to her target award for one full year
($3,250,000).</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(8)&#160;&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi
signed a separation agreement with the Company effective August&nbsp;31, 2006.
The severance amount consists of the payouts under the Annual Cash Incentive
Plan ($855,000), the Cash-Based Long-Term Incentive Plan ($5,075,000) and
salary continuation through December&nbsp;31, 2006 ($369,231). These amounts
and any future amounts payable under his separation agreement are contingent
upon the satisfaction of restrictive covenant provisions, including
satisfaction of a one-year non-compete provision. Full terms of his separation
agreement are provided on page&nbsp;54.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(9)&#160;&#160; In
connection with Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi&#146;s separation agreement, 380,813 shares of
unvested Restricted Stock were canceled on August&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(10) Mr.&nbsp;Johnson
signed a separation agreement with the Company effective October&nbsp;31, 2006.
The severance amount consists of the payouts under the Annual Cash Incentive
Plan ($391,400), the Cash-Based Long-term Incentive Plan ($1,543,400) and a
lump sum payout paid upon signature of his separation agreement ($1,877,000).
These amounts and any future amounts payable under his separation agreement are
contingent upon the satisfaction of restrictive covenant provisions, including
satisfaction of a one-year non-compete provision. Full terms of his separation
agreement are provided on page&nbsp;55.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(11) In
connection with Mr.&nbsp;Johnson&#146;s separation agreement, 155,000 shares of
unvested Restricted Stock were canceled on October&nbsp;31, 2006. The amount
shown includes the forfeiture of restricted stock grants previously accrued
based on the FAS 123R valuation methodology that is used to value Restricted
Stock awards to all participants. Assumptions made in the valuation methodology
are disclosed in Note 11 to the consolidated financial statements contained in
the Company&#146;s Form&nbsp;10-K for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(12) For
consistency and where applicable, amounts have been converted to U.S. dollars
based on the December&nbsp;29, 2006 currency translation rates of 1 Swiss Franc
to $0.8173 and 1 Euro to $1.3139. </font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(13) The positive
value of the year-over-year change in the actuarial value of benefits earned
under the Switzerland Pension Fund of $187,162 is offset by the negative value
of year-over-year change in actuarial value of benefits earned under Kraft
Foods Germany Pension Plan of $192,643, resulting in a negative sum. A zero
value is provided for the change in pension value. The reason for the negative
actuarial value under the Kraft Foods Germany Pension Plan&#160; is a change in the discount rate used to
value the plan.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">39</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr height="0">
  <td width="31" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="7" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="137" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="16" style="border:none;"></td>
  <td width="4" style="border:none;"></td>

</table>

</div>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="80" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:59.75pt;"></div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)&#160;&#160; The amounts represent awards payable under the 2006 Annual Cash
Incentive Plan. The target amounts represent the potential payout if both business
performance and individual performance are at target levels. The maximum amount
represents the stockholder-approved maximum in the 2005 Performance Incentive
Plan. Actual amounts paid under the 2006 Annual Cash Incentive Plan are
disclosed in the Summary Compensation Table on page&nbsp;37.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(2)&#160;&#160; Awards granted to all named executive officers were in the form of
restricted stock. The grants are valued based on the fair market value on the grant
date. The fair market value is equal to the average of the high and low trading
prices as reported on the New York Stock Exchange&#151;Composite Transactions on the
grant date. </font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(3)&#160;&#160; </font>Restricted
shares granted to Mr. Deromedi on January 24, 2006 were canceled in connection
with his separation agreement dated August&nbsp;31, 2006.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(4)&#160;&#160; Restricted shares granted to Mr. Johnson on
January 24, 2006 were canceled in connection with his separation agreement
dated October&nbsp;31, 2006.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 12.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(5)&#160;&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Searer
was granted a one-time special restricted stock award in recognition of his promotion
to President Kraft North America Commercial.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">40</font></p> <br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<!-- SEQ.=1,FOLIO='40',FILE='C:\fc\72151635961_D10466_1856976\7513-1-dq.htm',USER='jmsproofassembler',CD='Mar 13 15:17 2007' -->
<br clear="all" style="page-break-before:always;">



<p style="font-weight:bold;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 10.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><b><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Employment Letter for Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld<a name="EmploymentLetterForMs_rosenfeld_212005"></a></font></b></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">For reasons discussed
in the Compensation Discussion&nbsp;&amp; Analysis, Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s
employment offer included the following terms:</font></p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>A
2006 annual incentive award based on one full year of service and payable in February&nbsp;2007
in an amount not less than $1,950,000;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>A
Long-Term Incentive Plan award for the 2004&#150;2006 performance cycle based on one
full year of service and payable in February&nbsp;2007 at her target of $3,250,000;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>Eligibility
for temporary housing for a period of up to one year from her date of
employment;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>A
sign-on restricted stock award of 387,230 shares with a grant value equal to
$12 million with terms and conditions substantially similar to grants made to
other executives with the following exceptions:</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 60.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">i.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>161,346 shares
will vest July&nbsp;1, 2009 and the remaining 225,884 shares will vest on July&nbsp;1,
2011, provided that if, prior to full vesting of the shares granted, Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld&#146;s
employment with the Company ends due to involuntary termination for reasons
other than cause, the total number of unvested shares will continue to vest on
the vesting dates stated above;</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 60.0pt;text-indent:-20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">ii.</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>The total number
of shares will also vest if (1)&nbsp;she fails to be named Chairman of the
Company&#146;s Board of Directors on or before January&nbsp;1, 2008 or (2)&nbsp;anyone
other than Mr.&nbsp;Camilleri or Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld is appointed Chairman of
the Company&#146;s Board of Directors; and</p>

<p style="font-family:Times New Roman;font-size:10.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 30.0pt;text-indent:-10.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Symbol" style="font-size:10.0pt;">&#183;</font><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:3.0pt;">&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font>An
enhanced retirement benefit which provides for credited service during the
period she was not employed by the Company between 2004 and 2006. The value of
this enhancement at current compensation levels is approximately $670,833.</p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">Also, the Company entered into separation agreements
with Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi and Mr.&nbsp;Johnson in 2006. The separation agreements
are summarized on pages&nbsp;54 and 55.</font></p>


 <p style="font-size:10.0pt;margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font face="Times New Roman">41</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)&#160;&#160; Market value of shares is based on the Company&#146;s December&nbsp;29,
2006 closing stock price of $35.70.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(2)&#160;&#160; Dividends
paid in 2006 on outstanding restricted stock awards for each of the named
executives officers were as follows: Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld; $185,870;&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi; $333,670;&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Dollive; $53,916;&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Johnson; $142,715;&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Roberts; $123,572;&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Searer; $52,416;&#160; and Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang; $80,546.</font></p>

dates for all outstanding unvested restricted stock awards are as follows:</font></p>

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="80" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:59.75pt;"></div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(a)&#160; Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld
was granted the restricted shares in connection with her hire and appointment
to Chief Executive Officer.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(b) Mr.&nbsp;Deromedi&#146;s
restricted shares were vested or canceled in connection with his separation
agreement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(c)&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Johnson&#146;s
restricted shares were canceled in connection with his separation agreement.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(d) Mr.&nbsp;Roberts
was awarded a special grant of restricted shares in connection with his promotion
to his current position.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt 20.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(e)&#160; Mr.&nbsp;Searer
was awarded a special grant of restricted shares in connection with his promotion
to his current position.</font></p>


 <p style="margin:24.0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:center;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">43</font></p>
</div><br><hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color="#010101" align="center">

  </td>
  <td width="109" colspan="3" valign="bottom" style="border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;border-left:none;border-right:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:81.8pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Number&nbsp;of&nbsp;Securities<br>
  Underlying<br>
  Unexercised&nbsp;Options<br>
  Unexercisable<br>
  (#)</font></b></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="border:none;border-top:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></b></p>

  <p style="font-weight:bold;line-height:8.0pt;margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:center;"><b><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:8.0pt;">Option&nbsp;Exercise<br>

  </td>
  <td width="68" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:50.9pt;">
  <p style="margin:6.0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;text-align:right;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">507,940</font></p>

  <td width="4" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:3.3pt;">

  <td width="6" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:4.7pt;">

<div style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;page-break-after:avoid;"><hr size="1" width="80" noshade color="black" align="left" style="width:59.75pt;"></div>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(1)&#160;&#160; Reflects the full vesting of the 2003 stock grant of 55,630 shares
on February&nbsp;3, 2006. Per his separation agreement, stock grants awarded in
2004 and 2005 partially vested on August&nbsp;31, 2006. Shares granted in 2006
were canceled upon his separation.</font></p>

<p style="margin:0pt 0pt 6.0pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:10.0pt;">(2)&#160;&#160; Reflects the full vesting of the 2003 stock grant on
February&nbsp;3, 2006.</font></p>

  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="37" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:28.1pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="25" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:18.8pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="37" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:28.1pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:8.9pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="61" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:46.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="12" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:8.9pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="19" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:14.5pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="19" colspan="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:13.9pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="23" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:17.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="2" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:1.7pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#CCEEFF" style="page-break-inside:avoid;">
  <td width="201" colspan="3" valign="top" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:150.95pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt 18.0pt;text-indent:-9.0pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">Global Supply Chain</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  <p align="left" style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:left;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">Pension Fund</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="37" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:28.1pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="25" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:18.8pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;text-align:right;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:9.0pt;">9.1</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="37" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:28.1pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:6.5pt;position:relative;top:-3.0pt;">(5)</font></p>
  </td>
  <td width="16" valign="bottom" style="padding:0pt .7pt 0pt 0pt;width:12.0pt;">
  <p style="margin:0pt 0pt .0001pt;"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman" style="font-size:1.0pt;">&nbsp;</font></p>

  </td>
